qas.question: What were the main types of loans in Sumerian society?
What was trade credit backed by when extended by temples?
How man shekel per mina was the interest rate for loans?
For how long was the interest rate of Sumerian loans consistent?
What typically arose as a result of unpaid obligations?
Who extended personal credit to citizens?
What was set at 1/60 a month after 2000 BC?
Who lent money to farmers to plant crops?

context: <a0_0>Commercial credit and agricultural consumer<a0_0/> loans were the main types of loans. The trade credit was usually extended by <b5_0>temples<b5_0/> in order to finance trade expeditions and was nominated in <a1_0>silver<a1_0/>. The <b6_0>interest rate<b6_0/> was set at 1/60 a month (<a2_0>one<a2_0/> shekel per mina) some time before 2000 BC and it remained at that level for <a3_0>about two thousand years<a3_0/>. <a4_0>Rural loans<a4_0/> commonly arose as a result of unpaid obligations due to an institution (such as <b7_0>a temple)<b7_0/>, in this case the arrears were considered to be lent to the debtor. They were denominated in barley or other crops and the interest rate was typically much higher than for commercial loans and could amount to 1/3 to 1/2 of the loan principal.
